column1: Between 29 April 2022 and 30 November 2022, will North Korea detonate a nuclear device?
column6: ['Technology', 'Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
Passage of time
Oops February 2023
February it’s already set up ready to go on timed detonator

\With supposed news that North Korea is making powerful nuclear devices making this an actual possibility. But with how close we are to the date I think it's impossible for a nuclear device to be detonated now. All the planning and setting up that would take to detonate these devices would take way too long and unless they have been planning it before and had a set day of the last day, this will probably not happen.

North Korea stated that it is planning on creating one of the most powerful nuclear weapons. These weapons require multiple tests and attempt to create the nuclear weapon. By the end of November 30th, I do not believe that they will detonate a nuclear device. There has been no indication of a nuclear threat and South Korea indicates that they do not foresee North Korea launching a nuclear device anytime before November 30th.
https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2022/11/103_340681.html
North Korea announced it is planning to become the most powerful nuclear power in the world, which would require various tests at different stages.
Not sure if North Korea can stand the consequences of such move - especially consequences of a mistaken hit on Japan or South Korea
(no change) Perhaps if KJU is participating and wants to save his Brier score ;-)
Not many days left here

If NK wanted to/could detonate a nuclear device, in the next 4 days, they would have done it by now. There is so much saber rattling, if nuclear weapons were on the table, I think they would have been used. Also, Xi seems to be making overtures that Kim would be foolish to douse with a weapons test and the news is not blowing up about the readiness of a nuclear weapons site which I think they would be if it was obvious. It always pains me to bet on Kim, but I think I have to.
Given North Korea has not denote nuclear weapons in since 2017 + the window mentioned by the question is extremely short, think the question has a close to 0 probability (<0.5%)

Not going to show the math, but doing a rather simple calculation that factors in (subjective) progress x time elapsed (in the style of @Ken_Barns), then adjusted up three-fold to sort of acknowledge reports of a November window that is narrowing but is still there due to suspicious reporting regarding Kim Jong-un and his military activities, one of which features his daughter and many of which feature rockets. Lots of rockets. That land in open water . . . that nobody seems to pick up. Will they land on a fisherman's boat one day? I don't know. #RocketMan :)
With less than a week left, and the World Cup ongoing. I doubt it.
Time decay
It could happen any time [1], but probably won't before this question expires.

Underlying trends would suggest that this event is still a strong possibility in the near future; however, I’m less convinced that it will occur in the next week. Un is often noted to enjoy comforts and practices from outside of the DPRK; hopefully, he’s stayed home to watch the WC!

Adjusting for time but I still don't know. I highly doubt it will happen. it doesn't seem like he has the capability, but with all of the recent missile launches his desire may overwhelm his caution.

There is very much a chance that a nuclear weapon may be detonated in a "test", but it seems like time is running low and I don't see much action being taken before December arrives. North Korea missed the particularly warm and sunny weather to do the tests in.

I don't like gambling on Kim Jong Un, especially after the recent ICBM test, but with time running out, I feel like I need to decrease the probability. Also, I think that the number of non-nuclear demonstrations are actually a sign pointing against an imminent nuclear test. This feels like a way to assert strength despite not having the ability/desire to do it nucearly.

NEW: Kim Jong-un's daughter was being reported at one of the military events, seemingly a show to the public. To me it ticks up the probability, but also time passing is too quick. Also, since nothing has happened since this news, maybe it's less likely, even with the leader's special person - in this case his daughter.

NK leadership praising their progress in military (and nuclear?) capabilities, showcase of which was the most recent "successful" ICBM test launch towards Hokkaido capable of carrying nuclear warheads (likely Hwasong-17).
Not long to go and no test since 2017
it seems North Korea isn't willing to move past the nuclear threshold at this time, choosing to continue ICBM tests instead.

Adjusting for time passed

Walking back from the brink. After President Biden attempted to link of improved U.S. China relations with China taking actions to prevent another nuclear test, this seems like a less likely outcome. If China understands that this is an important goal for de-escalation, then the hope is that they'll take Biden's comment seriously and at least have conversations with their ally. I'm down-grading to a toss up.

Moving my forecast much lower. I don't understand why a test has not yet happened. I think one will be soon, but it's looking increasingly likely that it'll be after Nov 30.

Down 10% for passage of time. If it happens I believe it will be to support programmatic issues. —if the designs are ready.

Tomorrow (today in NK; it's 2am there now) and Thursday are forecast to be sunny at the Punggye-ri testing site. These will be the first sunny days since the joint US/ROK military exercises ended. As I have written before, all previous DPRK nuclear tests have occurred between 9am and 12pm in sunny weather, so I think sunny mornings are most likely.
Time
Despite concrete UN/IAEA warning, nothing seems to have happened so far, two weeks to go...
Very low incentive to do so, and they lack resources ahead of the winter. Also, I doubt China would allow it ATM.

I start to doubt NK is able to do so. Maby they putting up the pressure to South Korea and US by pretending to be able to. Kim might be trolling us all. Besides, with all the ballistic launches this year, NK will definitely be short on recources, inkl. cash.

North Korea first launched an ICBM in 2017 which brought about concerns that the use of nuclear weapons would be next. The most recent nuclear detonation was in 2017 as well. Through efforts under President Trump, North Korea claimed that they would destroy all of their nuclear enrichment facilities. Despite this, recent satellite imagery would suggest that North Korea has restarted its reactor which makes weapons grade plutonium. Additionally, IAEA Chief Grossi claims that there is evidence of a nuclear test site reopening. This in conjunction with North Korea's recent tests with ballistic, hypersonic, and cruise missiles has developed a cause for concern. This has also led the Director of National Intelligence to predict that there will be a chance of North Korea demonstrating a rocket that could reach the US and make another claim towards global power. Despite this, with the clock rapidly running out, it is unlikely that North Korea will detonate another nuclear weapon within the next 16 days.

North Korea's recent activity suggests that it is likely, 65% chance, that they will detonate a nuclear device before 30 November 2022. According to VOA news North Korea test fired what appeared to be an intercontinental ballistic missile or ICBM, two short range ballistic missiles, and separately at least 23 missiles in one day all during November 2022. Reuters states that King Jong Un said that the launch of two long-range strategic missiles was to test the reliability and operation of nuclear-capable weapons. Lastly CNN states that North Korea has been preparing previously shut down nuclear testing sites. Based on the test firing of nuclear capable ICBM's, a statement from Kim Jong Un on the reason of the missile tests, and the preparation of an underground nuclear testing site, I believe that there is a 65% chance that North Korea will detonate a nuclear device before 30 November 2022.

In total, North Korea has tested a total of 6 nuclear weapons in a period from 2006-2017 (A timeline of North Korea's nuclear tests - CBS News). Since the last test, NK had stated they shut down their testing sight back in 2018 stating that it now is used to house a reactor to provide electricity (North Korea claims to have demolished nuclear test site | Fox News). This can be assumed to some degree of certainty to be a cover-up for the time as North Korea this year has now yet again fired ICBMs. Recent developments concerning China and The United States show concern for North Korea proceeding to test again soon. This was demonstrated by President Biden’s recent meeting with Xi Jinping concerning the test (Biden warns Xi of 'defensive' action if North Korea conducts new nuclear test (nbcnews.com). Based on this alone, it can be predicted about a 5 percent chance they will be testing nukes in the next 16 days.

The reporters Jennifer Jett, Stella Kim, and Arata Yamamoto said that after launching an Intercontinental Ballistic Missile for the first time since 2017, there were concerns that North Korea may use another nuclear weapon. The most recent nuclear detonation was used in 2017. But in 2018, North Korea said they would destroy all their nuclear material enrichment facilities. The intel that we collected noted, according to the IAEA, the satellite suggests that North Korea has restarted its reactor, which makes weapon-grade plutonium.
lowering as time runs out.

North Korean missile tests and escalatory threats appear to have lessened in the last week (see https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests), reducing my probability of an imminent nuclear test.
Down 10% for passage of time. I still (obnoxiously often repeat) believe any test would be driven by readiness and need related to newer designs.
Hasn't happened yet and it seems like NK's primary method is launching ballistic missiles. All the same, the situation is still very volatile.
12% adjusting for time passed
12% adjusting for time passed
Time decay

It seems like the US and its allies in the region are coordinating in a response in the event of a 7th test [1]. This seems to indicate that there is still a fair chance North Korea will test in the near future, but lowering because there aren't that many days left in this question period.
What needs to happen for this to be true?
Time decay

I believe there is high probability they already have, but that it is not public knowledge. I don't put it above North Korea to detonate low grade nuclear weapon missiles over Japan. Enough to promote low-grade sickness, but not to kill, with higher rates of long-term problems, towards a country that already has nuclear contamination. Weakening Japan has too many advantages for its competing adversaries, has already been the subject of environmental contamination and is strategically tempting as a chip among its adversaries to make a bold statement with. The timing is right, considering Russia's needs where Ukraine is concerned, China's tension with the United States regarding Taiwan and other matters, and North Korea's politics. I believe that if they did detonate a low-grade nuclear device over Japan, Japan would handle it like they did Fukushima and publicly knowledge of it would be suppressed. Given North Korea's history, I believe it is highly likely that North Korea will detonate a nuclear device soon, so that the world has no choice but to acknowledge it. They will do so for leverage and brinkmanship. North Korea's detonation of a nuclear weapon is contingent on concession making on the part of the west and western affiliates and allies. However, concessions are not necessarily a good idea. The losses in the long run for short term gain where concessions are made is too problematic. China has the most promise, where talks take place, with the right skill and savvy. However, I'm not certain anyone has this to offer, to date. I place my estimate at 50/50 because I believe North Korea will detonate a nuclear weapon by the end of spring 2023, but I am less certain they will do it by November 30, 2022, based on current trajectories.
Down 20% for passage of time.

I used a prediction market to calibrate my guess. I realized my previous estimates of the probability of both Russia and/or North Korea took it over 50%. But I think it's around that but probably lower collectively. Having said that, when I average my calibrated probability with my best guess probability, it's somewhere around 40%. But going to more or less maintain for now since this particular time period in November has been the focus for months. It's a prime testing period should someone make that decision to go forward with the detonation.

Not a very strong update and building from some shaky suspicions that may not even be directly applicable, but, from this article [1], it seems North Korea may be subject to systematic reliability problems. If that is in fact the case, it could mean that, even if they wanted to test on a particular date, it might have to be delayed to run more subtests to give the test the best chance of success. Pairing that with the time left in this question causes me to continue to lower my estimates at a fairly rapid clip.
Next Wednesday is currently forecast to be sunny.
Time decay
Down another 10% for passage of time.

"no new activity of significance" observed at nuclear test site - this causes me to update down on there being a test in the very short term. It's still fairly likely because NK may wish to conduct a test as a response to the Vigilant Storm US/SK military exercises, but less likely if no new activity has been observed.
Down 5% for passage of time.

With only 22 days to go before the question closes, it seems there is still significant uncertainty and disagreement between experts, which in turn would seem to advise away from extreme forecasts (toward either Yes or No) and toward rather moderate ones.
Dropping slightly, as the US midterm elections are today, but I still think it's extremely likely that NK will conduct a test this month.
Time

Don't think the crowd forecast is properly accounting for time decay, as the most likely time for a nuclear test has effectively passed (post CCP congress, pre US election). Seems like NK has made adequate preparations for a test but historically have orchestrated such events around things like national holidays (e.g., early Sept).
And now the only sunny days in the 10-day forecast are Nov 16 and 17.
After reviewing more evidence my first guess was probably pretty low.
Although the term "nuclear", in weapon terms, has currently become more common there's little evidence that NK will test another time.

Maintaining my forecast. The US/ROK joint exercises ended Saturday. The only 2 sunny days in the current forecast are Tuesday, Nov 8 and Thursday, Nov 17, so I think those are most likely for the near future.
War games are finished

My previous steep reduction was based on the assumption that NK would test a nuclear warhead around some important regime holidays. That seems to not be the case as the escalations have increased since the last important political holiday. The next one this year is Mother's Day and we all know moms really like nuclear tests lol :D

It seems that we have gotten through Friday morning without a nuclear test. Let's see how the next few days go. The US and South Korea have extended military exercises through Saturday, so perhaps Kim might not start a test until after then.
North Korea has all but warned that they’re about to do another test. I expect one within the next 2-5 hours, although anytime in the next few days is also possible.

Updated: 50->60->70, +10 for second consecutive day of missile tests during US drills (+5) and the escalation of including an ICBM w/i today's set of missile tests (+5). I did some further thinking on this and, as it turns out, DPRK nuclear tests are not all that unlikely. Between 2006 and 2021, the average number of number of tests/year is 37.5%, so, under normal circumstances, we might find that it's a reasonable to guess that a test will occur at a rate of about 1/2.66 years. The last was in 2017, so, I say with complete seriousness, we might be overdue? :-(
Missile activity
North Korea's recent behaviour suggests a test in the next few days is increasingly likely, as many others have pointed out.

very unpredictable, but this article made me reduce the probability that this will take place within the next 35 days. With Russia and China taking most of the media coverage space right now, NK might fell less urgency in performing power displays.

The detonation of a nuclear bomb would result in further sanctions. The UN Security Council sanctions of March 2013 included travel bans and account freezes. The economic situation in North Korea is said to be precarious. North Korea has been dependent on food aid from outside for many years. In my opinion, it will not dare to detonate a nuclear bomb. Kim Jong Un (and his sister Kim Yo-jong) will look very closely at the situation in the Russia-Ukraine war, but he will also hold back for the time being.
Bad timing

I don't think it'll be tomorrow, because then it would look like Kim Jong Un was waiting for Xi Jinping's meeting, and the Supreme Leader doesn't want to look second to anyone. So I'd expect it to happen any time after a few days from now, probably in October, based on historical data, but possibly in November.

Nuclear proliferation and testing remains an ongoing concern with respect to North Korea. While the time horizon for this IFP is slowly degrading, the likelihood of this event remains. While this remains a rare event, forecasting questions of such type are notoriously difficult despite incomplete information.

Testing wont happen due to destruction of the North Korean test facility during last test

Except for its first, all past DPRK weapons tests have occurred within 18 months of a South Korean parliamentary election. Outside of nuclear tests, the DPRK has a tendency to engage in "provocations" around the time of South Korean elections, broadly speaking. We won't see a new election for the ROK's National Assembly until 2024. There doesn't seem any reason for the DPRK to break its operational pattern.
https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/skorea-spy-agency-says-nkorea-nuclear-test-may-occur-between-oct-16-nov-7-yonhap-2022-09-28/

The available evidence and statements by public officials suggest to me that NK is planning a nuclear test. Previous tests have taken place in Jan, Feb, May, Sept, Sept and Oct, between 9:00am and 12:30pm, with fall dates chosen for good weather and summer dates supposedly avoided because of bad weather. So I think sometime this month or next is most likely, once weather damage to their testing facility is repaired. Some are suggesting that a test might be timed to US VP Harris' East Asian tour this week. Otoh, the US has laid out some consequences to testing that NK might want to avoid. But they largely just don't seem to care what the US wants.
Down 10% for passage of time.

The main reason why I think North Korea would detonate a device would be to signal strength to the West. It seems like NK is choosing to do that through ballistic missile activities instead of nuclear activities. I still would not be shocked if NK detonated a nuclear device, but I believe the chances are lower than I used to.
They are not interested in attracting that kind of attention again.

North Korea test the weapon 6 times in past 15 years and intervals between them are 5 years or so. If I assume they will test it in 1 or 2 years, still the probability is like 2/24 because it is september 15 now. Therefore, I have chosen this number.

The usual reason for such pyrotechnics is that The Pyongyang Kid feels he is getting too little attention from The Big Kids. He probably still isn't, and is therefore likely to become a bit unstable on some front fairly soon. He is neither stupid nor crazy, but for guessing out what he might do, it has been helpful to think of him as a reasonably bright 7th-grade boy. He can only behave himself for so long. Stay tuned.

Historically, Kim Jong-un has spaced out his missile testing and nuclear activity to maximize his apparent strength without provoking international powers to the point that they might threaten the status quo in his country."

NK conducted 6 tests in the last 16 years. This makes 37% probability in a given year if the trend continues. In the remaining 3.5 months that makes about 11%. However, NK in 2022 has increased the missile launch tests to roughly 31 from 8 last year. This indicates a significantly higher appetite to show its military strength. I would increase the probability to around 15%, which would mean almost certainty of a test within 2 years, which is an implied assumption i think is reasonable.
Passage of time. Few rumors. Maybe chances are the highest during Oktober and November due to the weather.
Down 5% for passage of time. Would go lower except for the old IC public pronouncements.

I am finally making a long overdue return to this question. Intelligence agencies of various governments continue to publicly report that North Korea has prepared their site for a nuclear test and that a nuclear test could be imminent. However, the timelines for this test remain unclear and time continues to pass without a test. Current political tensions make it unclear to me whether NK would benefit more from performing a test before question close, or not performing such a test.

They have not detonated one for 5 years. They lied about doing one in March 2022. There are 3.5 months left of this challenge. Why is the crowd forecast thinking it’s more likely than not? Without knowing much about what North Korea is up to right now, it seems very unlikely they will detonate another within the available window.
One madman being egged on by another madman

I would increase the probability to around 15%, which would mean almost certainty of a test within 2 years, which is an implied assumption i think is reasonable.

Kim Jong Un recovered from COVID. The rainy Season is almost over, so it gets more likey as we get closer to the season of fall.

Doing some simple calculations, we can see that the probability that North Korea will conduct a nuclear test in a year is around 36.4% (naive calculation of 4 times / 11 years). On September 3, 2017, the Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Facility reopened and Is likely to be used for testing of miniaturized nuclear warheads for various, ICBMs, LRBMs, and SRBMs. It was used for the largest nuclear test (100 - 300 kiloton bomb), more devastating than the bomb dropped at Hiroshima. NK recently tested a hypersonic missile in January along with a more recent flight test this month. There is some dispute among analysts in various ICs about whether the Kwasong 15 used in a military display in March is real; this ICBM has been designed and is in development. It has not been flight tested and is a likely candidate for the next series of tests. North Korea has recently reopened the Tongbyon nuclear reactor in March of this year, continuing plutonium separation and uranium enrichment activities. These activities likely supports its current military and political strategy (more below). NK holds an advantage in its asymmetric military balance with South Korea. On April 26, Kim made a series of statements which has been assessed by the ICs that indicates a significant shift in its nuclear ambitions and strategy. Major powers find this worrying to say the least. The Kwasong-17 flight tested in March but prematurely exploded according to SK IC. Kim’s statements indicate an increased likelihood of using nuclear weapons to resolve various crises (domestically, an internal regime crisis within its military apparatus and threats of regime change - the latter possible but highly unlikely to occur). US IC assesses that these recent nuclear tests indicate Kim’s need to demonstrate advanced military capabilities, use for blackmail diplomacy and to raise threats in order to receive potential economic and political concessions from its adversaries. It also tests strategic and tactical weapons to boost the morale of its military where serious grievances exist along with severe food shortages within its ranks.
